https://www.loom.com/share/68ee0d067a234b26976556ca5e33bbf6

title: Failing analyses should show an error
body:
When an analysis errors because it results in too many points, two important things need to happen:

- If we focus, we need to re-run that analysis, because now it might not result in too many points
- We need to tell the user that this analysis is no longer loading and is in an error state, and they should probably use focus to try and get a narrower working window

It's a little hard to tell from this replay that the log message for "Too many points" is indeed linked to the request to run the analysis, so I created https://github.com/RecordReplay/devtools/pull/6575 to make sure that we are also logging the protocol request ID. Using that locally I confirmed that this is what is happening here.

https://app.replay.io/recording/analysis-never-moves-beyond-loading--ff87d6b7-bebd-4c6b-8806-6a4b6e478bb5

title: Log the id of the failed protocol message
body:
It's hard to track down exactly which command failed when you don't have
an ID to go along with it.

title: Focus Mode 1.1

labels.name: Project
labels.description: Large collection of issues related to one goal

body:
**Background**

Focus Mode is missing some important stuff. [Here's a loom](https://www.loom.com/share/c84c600cb7684fc7bf65d8c2fd2d07ee) proposing some good improvements.

[Here's the original design ticket](https://github.com/RecordReplay/design/issues/28)
[Figma link](https://www.figma.com/file/mAotNZRv6M5X0zHIFKPzFY/?node-id=11491%3A103519)
[Discord thread](https://discord.com/channels/779097926135054346/968316622475513976)

**Details**

* We have a new precision editor in the bottom-right corner
* We default the timeline to a smaller window, rather than requiring it
* We have save, cancel, and discard now
* It's possible to drag the window right and left by clicking in the middle of it
* At first the window follows your cursor, then when you click you can drag the gripper edges as before

title: Comment client architecture followup

labels.name: Project
labels.description: Large collection of issues related to one goal

labels.name: feature-comments
labels.description: Comments / Transcripts in both View and Debug mode

body:
Build on top of PR #6335.

I propose we consider making the following changes to the way we model our comments in state:
- [ ] Move _pending_ comments out of Redux and into Apollo.
- [ ] Update the server to also be aware of the (currently local-only) `isPending` attribute, but maybe rename it to `isPublished`.
- [ ] Comments that have not been "published" should only be visible to their authors, (so the server should filter them).
  * Pressing _enter_ should "publish" a comment and make it visible to others.
  * Pressing _escape_ should cancel it (maybe with a confirmation?)
  * Focusing somewhere else should save it (in unpublished mode) for later.
    * Unpublished comments should look different (so the author knows they aren't shared).

The above changes will give us the ability to support multiple pending comments in parallel. (Clicking out of a comment won't have to reset/drop pending content.) They will also let us remember "draft" comments between sessions or if the devtools happens to close before saving.

If we choose _not_ to make the above changes, I suggest we make the following UX change to pending comments:
- [ ] If the user clicks on a different part of the UI when a pending comment has text entered but not _saved_, we could prompt the user if they want to save or discard (rather than just erasing the content).

This will prevent people from accidentally losing unsubmitted comments (which can take a while to write and be frustrating to lose). This change is probably not relevant if we make the above data model changes, since we could just keep multiple pending comments around until the user explicitly cancels them ("Escape" key) or publishes/shares them ("Enter" key).

title: Analysis based react devtools backend

labels.name: Project
labels.description: Large collection of issues related to one goal

labels.name: feature-framework
labels.description: Currently React DevTools

body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/RecordReplay/devtools/discussions/6188
Originally posted by **bhackett1024** April 2, 2022 Currently we have a version of the react devtools backend which we load into every recording made using the replay browser. Any react on the page will detect this backend and call into it, and it will add annotations to the recording which clients inspecting the recording can read and use to reconstruct the react state at any point in the recording. This approach works but it doesn't scale well in a couple of ways: 1. The backend version is fixed for the lifetime of a recording, and a matching version of the frontend needs to be used in order to inspect its react state. This makes it hard to upgrade the frontend / backend without breaking support for older recordings. 2. The backend is a substantial amount of code, and if we wanted to do something similar for other framework devtools we would potentially need to load quite a bit of code into every recording, on the off chance the backend would be needed. It would be better if we didn't load a specific version of the backend into each recording. There is already an interface between the devtools backend and the react code running on the page which works across different versions of react. If the client loaded both the frontend and the backend for the react devtools (where the versions always match), and inspected the recording to find all the sites where react would have called into the backend, it should be able to extract the necessary information from those sites to populate its copy of the backend with the react state changes made throughout the recording. We should be able to find the sites where react would have called into the backend by loading a shim version of the backend into each recording which is much smaller and just annotates the recording with all the calls that react is making. The main unknowns for me is understanding what information the backend needs from these sites in order to work, and how difficult it would be to get this information from the recording instead of values that are being passed in. I suspect the protocol is not expressive enough yet to deal with this use case. Mainly, each site will be a different pause point, and we don't have a way to compare objects between different pauses. So if the backend keeps track of metadata for a react object at one site, it won't be able to determine that object's metadata when it is accessed at a different site. We've wanted to address this limitation for a while though, and being able to improve the architecture of our react devtools support and address the above difficulties would be a good impetus for this.

title: Add qualifier filters to the library
body:
This is so not done don't look!

### Spec
Allow the users to use GitHub-style filter syntax in the library's search box.
- [x] It should be able to handle a `created` filter, e.g. `created:YYYY-MM-DD`
  - [ ] Write tests
  - [ ] Make it not gross (add input validation, better guards, use useContext, etc)
- [x] It should be able to handle a `target` filter, e.g. `target:node`
  - [ ] Write tests
  - [ ] Make it not gross (add input validation, better guards, use useContext, etc)
- [ ] Changes should apply after the user hits enter
  - Felt strongly about this even if we were doing the filtering on the server. The current implementation does the filtering on the client (for now), on each keypress, and perf is _bad_. So we should fix this 100%.
- [ ] Filters should be persisted in the URL so they stay intact on refresh
  - [ ] If the user opens a team link with filters in the URL, but they're not a part of that team, they should be redirected to their main library
  - [ ] The library should be able to use the filters in the URL when fetching the recordings

title: Research Redux DevTools packages (global variables and component integration)
body:
At a bare minimum, we have to integrate some of the actual component packages from the Redux DevTools codebase in to our app, similar to how we do it for the React DevTools.

Additionally, rather than creating our own variations of the global data hooks for `compose` and `send` and such, we ought to review how the DevTools Extension generates those and figure out if there's a good way to reuse the existing logic and have redirect to our own usage instead.

title: React DevTools extension is not enabled for Replay devtools

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: Tooling
labels.description: Tests, Logrocket

labels.name: feature-framework
labels.description: Currently React DevTools

body:
The React DevTools extension is only "enabled" (visible in the browser DevTools) on pages where React has been detected. For some reason (haven't dug in yet) the Replay devtools client isn't detected and so the React DevTools extension will never be enabled.

To "work around this" I have to first visit another website built with React (like https://reactjs.org/), open the browser DevTools, and then navigate _back_ to Replay devtools.
